BC-SPOT-BUDGET-BOS 
  
 For Release TUESDAY AMs, May 25, 1999  
 

   The Boston Globe plans to move the following stories for use by
NYTimes News Service clients.

        For questions about stories, contact    Frank Perrotta    at the
Boston Globe,    617-929-2597.    For individual purchase of graphics
or photos please call 212 556-4204 or -1927.

   All stories will bear the BOS designator.

       

     CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS       (i)  

   YUGOSLAVIA (Washington) _ Russian envoy says he has bridged one
of the central gaps in peace negotiations between NATO and
Yugoslavia, convincing Western powers of the importance of letting
some Yugoslav forces stay inside Kosovo after the bombing stops. By
Anne E. Kornblut. 1200 words.

     INTERNATIONAL (i)  

   ISRAEL-BARAK (Tel Aviv) _ Prime Minister-elect Ehud Barak begins
party talks aimed at forming a broad government that will be able
to tackle some of Israel's most formidable problems. By Aliza
Marcus. 900 words.

     WASHINGTON (w)  

   COURT-BIAS (Washington) _ Educators who fail to stop students
from sexually harassing other students may be violating a federal
anti-bias law and can be forced to pay damages, Supreme Court
rules. By Mary Leonard. 1200 words.

     NATIONAL (a)  

   CELLPHONE-RESEARCH (Undated) _ Scientists studying links between
cellular telephone use and cancer are furious that preliminary
research data was leaked to suggest cell phones may be linked to
brain tumors. By Peter Howe. 800 words.

   NY-PATAKI (New York) _ Gov. George Pataki's endorsement of
George W. Bush is being seen by both parties as a swat at New York
City mayor Rudolph Giuliani. By Fred Kaplan. 800 words.

   PATRIOTS-STADIUM (Boston) _ As Governor Paul Cellucci signs the
$70 million Patriots stadium bill, team owner Robert Kraft meets
with his NFL peers to discuss the league's financing contribution.
By Gregg Krupa. 1000 words. (a and s coding)

     FINANCIAL (f)  

   THERMO-RESTRUCTURE (Undated) _ Under pressure from large
shareholders, Thermo Electron will announce a restructuring as Dick
Syron, former head of the American Stock Exchange, takes the reins.
By Ross Kerber. 750 words.

   CLINTON-LEAVE (Undated) _ Work-family advocates hail President
Clinton's speech advocating using unemployment benefits for
emergency leaves. Opponents say such a plan would cost $200 million
per year and would put small firms at risk. By Diane E. Lewis. 500
words.  

   BELL-SERVICES (Boston) _ Seeking to beat the pack, Bell Atlantic
formally files to offer long-distance telephone service in
Massachusetts. By Bruce Mohl. 800 words.

     SPORTS (s)  

   BBA-REDSOX (New York) _ By Gordon Edes. (Eds.: The Red Sox
Yankees game has been postponed due to rain.)

   BKN-RYAN-COLUMN (New York) _ By Bob Ryan.

     The Boston Globe
